botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Ingestion may cause a severe discomfort. Skin irritant. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling.
botanical_details.genus: Helleborus can be rhizomatous, herbaceous or semi-evergreen perennials forming a clump of pedate basal leaves, or evergreen with erect, leafy stems. Large, bowl-shaped flowers are borne in loose clusters in late winter or spring

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in fertile, moisture retentive, but well drained, preferably neutral to alkaline soil in a position sheltered from strong winds in sunny spot or light shade. Improve lighter soil with organic matter such as garden compost or a manure-based soil conditioner prior to planting and mulch well. For more advice see hellebore cultivation.
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate large clumps by division in early spring for home use only.
how_to_grow.pruning: Remove faded or damaged foliage in autumn, winter before the flowers appear.
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to hellebore aphids, slugs and snails.
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to hellebore black death, hellebore leaf spot, grey moulds (botrytis) and virus diseases.
